title: 109_hr3562
content: The "Specialty Crop and Value-Added Agriculture Promotion Act" defines specialty crops to include fish, shellfish, and organically produced crops. It also authorizes permanent appropriations for state specialty crop block grants. Subsection (i) of the Specialty Crops Competitiveness Act of 2004 is amended to authorize $500,000,000 for grants to the Secretary of Agriculture annually. The Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include a grant program for states based on the total value of agricultural commodities produced. The Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include a grant program for states based on the total value of agricultural commodities produced. The grant funds are limited to $3,000,000 per State and must be used to award competitive grants to eligible independent producers for developing business plans and marketing strategies for value-added agricultural products. The Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include a grant program for states to assist eligible agricultural producer groups, cooperatives, or business ventures in developing business plans and marketing strategies for value-added agricultural products in emerging markets. The competitive grants are limited to $3,000,000 per State. The Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include a grant program for states to assist eligible agricultural producer groups, cooperatives, or business ventures in developing business plans and marketing strategies for value-added agricultural products in emerging markets. The total amount provided to a grant recipient shall not exceed $500,000, with restrictions on the amount for producer-based business ventures. Grant recipients must use the funds to develop a business plan or perform a feasibility study for marketing. The Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include a grant program for states to assist agricultural producer groups in developing business plans and marketing strategies for value-added agricultural products. Grant recipients must use the funds to develop a business plan or perform a feasibility study for marketing opportunities or to establish alliances for better market competition. States are required to submit reports on fund usage, and $100,000,000 is allocated annually for this program. The Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 is amended to provide $100,000,000 for a grant program to assist states in developing business plans and marketing strategies for value-added agricultural products. The term 'State' includes all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The effective date for this amendment is October 1, 2005. SEC. 5. REIMBURSEMENT OF CERTIFICATION COSTS. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish an incentive program for third-party certification of agricultural producers and processors to enhance marketability. Standards will be set for certification types and related expenses eligible for reimbursement, capped at 50%. The incentive program for third-party certification of agricultural producers and processors will reimburse up to 50% of qualified expenses incurred for accepted certifications. SEC. 6. Nationwide expansion of Risk Management Agency Adjusted Gross Revenue Insurance Program. The Federal Crop Insurance Act is amended to make the adjusted gross revenue insurance pilot program a permanent nationwide program starting in 2006. The program may expand to cover any county with crop production, with temporary premium subsidies available for producers in counties with high specialty crop production and low insurance participation. The Comptroller General will study the Federal crop insurance program to assess its effectiveness for specialty crop producers and recommend improvements. SEC. 7 of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to expand the fruit and vegetable program in school lunch programs by adding a new section 19. The Secretary will provide free fruits and vegetables to schools, with priority given to states producing specialty crops. Schools must publicize the program, and $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2006 and 2007. SEC. 8 of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act increases the limit on direct operating loans to $500,000, indexed to inflation. SEC. 9 focuses on the trade of specialty crops. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to establish the position of Assistant USTR for Specialty Crops, responsible for promoting trade interests, removing trade barriers, and enforcing trade agreements for specialty crop businesses. Specialty Crops will be compensated at the level of a Senior Executive Service member. A study will be conducted by the Comptroller General on the benefits of agreements for specialty crop businesses. The Secretary of Agriculture must create a foreign market access strategy within a year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Agriculture must develop a foreign market access strategy to increase exports of specialty crops. SEC. 10. The authorization for technical assistance for specialty crops is increased from $2,000,000 to $10,000,000.
